_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Chlorination equipment meets the standards of the Chlorine Institute
_prev_prog_2.Description: The Hanover Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant uses chlorine gas for disinfection of treated wastewater.  The gas is received in one-ton containers and dissoved into water using vacuum feed chlorination with leak detection.  A gas detector and alarm system is connected to an automatic telephone dialer.  Two people unload a delivery truck with a crane hoist, an approved lifting device.  Empty chlorine containers are exchanged by a team of two operators.  Self-contained breathing apparatus is available on-site.  The Adam County Defensive Hazardous Materials Response Team is the delegated first-responder and uses an emergency response plan developed by the Adams County LEPC as a result of SARA III and EPCRA reporting.  Additionally, supported is provided by the Cumberland County Hazardous Response Team, if needed.  The release risk management program in place at the facility ensures that all equipment, including process and safety equipment, is in excellent working condition.  A call-out list assures that there is round-the-clock coverage of operations of the facility.

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Replaced screens and filters in Sufonator
_prev_prog_2.Description: The Hanover Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant uses sulfur dioxide gas for dechlorination of treated wastewater.  The gas is received in one-ton containers and dissoved into water using vacuum feed sulfonation having leak detection.  A gas detector and alarm system is connected to an automatic telephone dialer.  Two people unload a delivery truck with crane hoist, an approved lifting device.  Empty sulfur dioxide containers are exchanged by a team of two operators.  Self-contained breathing apparatus is available on-site.  The Adam County Defensive Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Response Team is the delegated first-responder and use an emergency response plan developed by the Adams County LEPC as a result of SARA III and EPCRA reporting.  Additionally, support is provided by the Cumberland County Hazardous Materials Response Team, if needed.  The release risk management program in place at the facility ensures that all equipment, including process and safety equipment, is in excellent working condition.  A call-out list assures that there is round-the-clock coverage of operations at the facility.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Borough of Hanover owns and operates a Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) whose service area includes Hanover and McSherrystown Boroughs, as well as Conewego Township and a portion of Penn Township, all in Adams County, Pennsylvania.  The WWTP, located at the end of O=Brien Lane in Conewego Township, processes up to 4.5 million gallons per day of wastewater and discharges to the South Branch Conewego Creek under NPDES Permit No. PA0026875.   Wastewater treatment processes include grit and coarse screenings removal, primary sedimentation, secondary activated sludge treatment, clarification, filtration, disinfection, and de-chlorination.  Solid material removed from this process is stabilized in anaerobic digesters, dewatered, and utilized for agricultural purposes through land application.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

The WWTP includes a disinfection system comprised of a chlorine container room, which contains two (2) one ton containers of chlorine liquefied under pressure, a chlorinator, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  Up to six (6) one ton containers may be on site simultaneously.  The chlorinator system extracts chlorine gas from the storage containers through vacuum regulators and dissolves this gas in water to form a disinfection solution that is used to kill pathogenic bacteria and micro-organisms in the treated wastewater effluent prior to its discharge into the creek. Treatment plant operators regularly check the chlorinator room and its equipment, inventorying the rate of chlorine use and adjusting the rate as necessary.  The maximum intended inventory for planning purposes is 12,000 pounds.

               To improve the water quality of the effluent discharged to the receiving stream, the WWTP utilizes sulfur dioxide gas, another regulated substance, to de-chlorinate its effluent through a process called ?sulfonation?.  The sul

These recommendations included improvements to written emergency standard operating procedures, development of an operator training program, and increased documentation of routine functions related to the performance of the two regulated processes.
